title: Open Redirect Protection Bypass

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
Hi

Report #281538 is fixed but Attacker can Bypass this Open Redirect Protection.

Give this link ``` https://twitter.com/teams/authorize?target_screen_name=&authorize_callback=//www.facebook.com``` to authorized victim.Twitter will say him to authorize a different account for create team.After authorization victim will be redirected to ```www.facebook.com```

Vulnerable point ```//www.facebook.com``` (You can use //www.example.com )

Open Redirection Protection Bypassed.

PoC video attached

With Best Regards
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi

Report #281538 is fixed but Attacker can Bypass this Open Redirect Protection.

Give this link https://twitter.com/teams/authorize?target_screen_name=&authorize_callback=//www.facebook.com to authorized victim.Twitter will say him to authorize a different account for create team.After authorization victim will be redirected to www.facebook.com

Vulnerable point //www.facebook.com (You can use //www.example.com )

Open Redirection Protection Bypassed.

PoC video attached

With Best Regards

activities.message:
Thank you for your report.

You state that #281538 is fixed. Can you elaborate on the difference between the behavior in #281538 and this report? What protection is being bypassed here that solved the problem in #281538?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report.

You state that #281538 is fixed. Can you elaborate on the difference between the behavior in #281538 and this report? What protection is being bypassed here that solved the problem in #281538?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Hi

In report #281538 i showed you how the link ```https://twitter.com/teams/authorize?target_screen_name=&authorize_callback=https://lenovo.com``` redirecting victim to ```https://lenovo.com```.Now this is mitigated and this link isn't redirecting victim to lenovo.com

But now again this link ```https://twitter.com/teams/authorize?target_screen_name=&authorize_callback=//www.facebook.com``` will redirect victim to facebook.com.
You can clearly see ``` I added two forward slashes //``` before ```www.facebook.com```

Difference to be noted:

1.Same as report #281538, if you don't add any forward slash before www.facebook.com then you will not get redirected to facebook.com
2.But If you go with ```more than one forward slashes``` then again the mitigated link will redirect you to facebook.com (which acts like the protection added for mitigation in report #281538 got bypassed with more than two forward slashes.

Best Regards
activities.markdown_message:
Hi

In report #281538 i showed you how the link https://twitter.com/teams/authorize?target_screen_name=&authorize_callback=https://lenovo.com redirecting victim to https://lenovo.com.Now this is mitigated and this link isn't redirecting victim to lenovo.com

But now again this link https://twitter.com/teams/authorize?target_screen_name=&authorize_callback=//www.facebook.com will redirect victim to facebook.com.
You can clearly see I added two forward slashes // before www.facebook.com

Difference to be noted:

1.Same as report #281538, if you don't add any forward slash before www.facebook.com then you will not get redirected to facebook.com
2.But If you go with more than one forward slashes then again the mitigated link will redirect you to facebook.com (which acts like the protection added for mitigation in report #281538 got bypassed with more than two forward slashes.

Best Regards

activities.message:
Hi

One more way for redirection ```https://twitter.com/teams/authorize?target_screen_name=&authorize_callback=/%2Fgoogle%252Ecom```

Crafted point: ```authorize_callback=/%2Fgoogle%252Ecom```

Best Regards

activities.message:
Hi @aarun 

Thanks for your comment.
It's all about the fix applied in report #281538
Where the previous vulnerable point ```authorize_callback=https://lenovo.com``` redirected the victim to lenovo.com,which is fixed now and the vulnerable point isn't redirecting victims to lenovo.com

But when i tried to put  ```authorize_callback=//lenovo.com``` in fixed vulnerable point then it again redirected victim to lenovo.com.
You can notice this time ```i added two slashes // before lenovo.com``` 

Vulnerable Url ```https://twitter.com/teams/authorize?target_screen_name=&authorize_callback=//www.lenovo.com``` will again redirect victim to lenovo.com

So vulnerability ```Open Redirect after Authorization``` occurs again.

Please Change the title of report so it will become more easy to understand.

With Best Regards
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @aarun

Thanks for your comment.
It's all about the fix applied in report #281538
Where the previous vulnerable point authorize_callback=https://lenovo.com redirected the victim to lenovo.com,which is fixed now and the vulnerable point isn't redirecting victims to lenovo.com

But when i tried to put authorize_callback=//lenovo.com in fixed vulnerable point then it again redirected victim to lenovo.com.
You can notice this time i added two slashes // before lenovo.com

Vulnerable Url https://twitter.com/teams/authorize?target_screen_name=&authorize_callback=//www.lenovo.com will again redirect victim to lenovo.com

So vulnerability Open Redirect after Authorization occurs again.

Please Change the title of report so it will become more easy to understand.

With Best Regards

activities.message:
Hi

Difference in behaviour you can notice : In report #281538 it's ```https://lenovo.com``` and now in this report i just removed only ```https:```so it become ```//lenovo.com``` .Now again vulnerable parameter redirected victim to lenovo.com(you can use //evil.com).

For reproduction give this link ```https://twitter.com/teams/authorize?target_screen_name=&authorize_callback=//lenovo.com``` to authorized victim and after authorization of his 2nd account he will be redirected to lenovo.com

Best Regards

Best Regards

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

activities.message:
It appears we missed awarding the bounty due to a mistake internally. I've corrected the issue so that we will be reviewing the issue at our next payouts meeting. Sorry about that!

Thanks for thinking of Twitter security!
